Award.AwardTitle: U-series Disequilibrium in Weddell Sea Sediments: Rates of Iceberg Discharge and Impact on Global Oceans
Award.AbstractNarration:
U-SERIES DISEQUILIBRIUM IN WEDDELL SEA SEDIMENTS: RATES OF ICEBERG DISCHARGE AND IMPACT ON GLOBAL OCEANS

ABSTRACT
Knowledge of the timescales of sedimentary processes is a fundamental pre-requisite for the study and understanding of the interplay between tectonics, climate and landscape evolution. Nevertheless, the vast majority of studies of geological archives focus on the age of sediments in the context of their deposition, in large part because sediment residence and transport time cannot be readily measured by absolute means.
Here, the PIs propose to implement a novel approach termed ?comminution dating? (DePaolo et al., 2006), to determine the transport time of fine clastic sediments produced by Antarctic subglacial erosion and deposited in the Weddell Sea over the last ~250 ka. The transport time for this material probably varies between glacial-interglacial stages, and is related to the flux of iceberg discharge into the Southern Ocean, a process that is controlled by climate, and on longer timescales by tectonics. Thus, it is also related to the relative contribution of the Antarctic Ice Sheet to global sea level changes. The proposed study focuses on U-series disequilibrium in detrital material, which as shown in previous studies, is a measure of weathering and transport time. The time elapsed since the initial grinding of the bedrock by glacial abrasion that produces rock flour, including the transport process and age of deposition, is defined as the ?comminution age? of the sediment, and is determined by the relative degree of 234U-depletion in the samples. Preliminary results show significant 234U-depletion in the proposed sediments, whereby the radioactive decay (activity) ratio of parent and daughter uranium isotopes is less than unity (i.e., (234U/238U)<1).
The results, which relate to several sub-disciplines in Earth Sciences, including geochronology, geochemistry, and paleoceanography, will provide conceptual and quantitative constraints on the rates of subglacial weathering in Antarctica during the late Quaternary, and their relation to climate changes and sea level changes. Furthermore, the results will provide the possibility to evaluate the impact of continental weathering on the evolution of marine (234U/238U) ratios, which is of importance in the context of U-Th dating methodology of corals. Another product of this study will be an archive of the long-term variations in the Weddell Sea authigenic end member composition, an important contributor to marine deepwater.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we focused on developing a novel method to quantify the sediment transport times of the siliciclastic fraction of marine cores. The knowledge of the timescales of sediment trasnport processes is a fundamental pre- requisite for the study and understanding of the interplay between tectonics, climate and landscape evolution. This is important particularily in Antarctica, where the combination between ice sheet expansion and shrinkage is closely coupled with global climate change and has a first order impact on the volume and comsposition of the oceans.

We investigated the application of "comminution dating" in the Weddell Sea over the last ~250 kyrs. This novel approach that makes use of U-disequilibrium in siliciclastic sediments, and evaluates the timespan between continental erosion and deposition. We further evaluated the potential source areas of the different sample fractions.

Our findings show that different fractions in the sediments have different sources and different transport times. The fine clay size particles originate in East Antarctica and show sediment transport times of up to ~300 kyrs. Sediments deposited during interglacial stages yield trasnport times <200 kyrs, while those deposited during glacials show longer transport times ca. 200-300 kyrs. These differences reflect secular changes in the intensity of the Antarctic Polar Current and trasnport efficiency. Thus, the export of fine terrigenous material from Antarctica into the oceans, including supply of nutrients that enhance primary productivity in the oceans, is determined to be stronger during interglacial times. During glacials, these processes are weaker.  The coarse silt-size fraction originates from closer source regions and shows similar patterns of interglacial-glacial transport times. 

In the East Weddell Sea, we found significant evidence for the presence of authigenic clays that formed in situ. The silt fraction in this region shows short transpot times and in general it appears that the site studied in East Weddell Sea refelcts a loval histroy.

To summerize, our first-of-its-kind investigation of comminution ages of marine cores from the Weddell Sea provides strong constraints on the geologic and oceanographic history of Antarctica and surrounding oceans during the late Quaternary and provides a basis for further investigation of the systematics of U-disequilibrium in marine sediments. One of the results of the study is the production of a high temporal and spatial resolution data set that is key to connecting provenance studies on the continent with similar studies of the history of the Southern Ocean.
